awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Reliable Monitoring and Predictive Modeling for Safer Future Smart Transportation Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern societies depend critically on their transportation infrastructure, in particular on the networks of roads. Hence, there is a growing need for an accurate and reliable assessment of the structural health condition of roads, especially of their subsurface courses (layers) responsible for roads’ structural strength and performance. The approaches to addressing these needs must be pervasive, scalable, sustainable, wireless, low-cost, low-power, high-resolution, and deployable for long durations of time, with negligible disturbances to the courses. Currently, existing monitoring techniques fall short of fulfilling these requirements, in one way or another. The project seeks to develop foundational technology that addresses this challenge. 

The key enablers of the proposed technology are tiny wireless Backscatter-based, Batteryless, Radiofrequency Sensors (BBRS), which sense the communication channel between themselves while communicating using backscatter modulation. BBRS measure the phase and amplitude of the communication links, which allow discerning of various material properties, and enable simultaneous monitoring of distances, relative displacements, strain, cracking, stiffness, humidity, and temperature throughout continuums of subsurface courses. BBRS are powered by an external RF signal provided by exciters installed on moving vehicles; the same RF signal which supplies the carrier for the backscattering. Information is carried among BBRS via multihop networking. BBRS are able to carry out some basic data processing. The aim of this project is to generate preliminary results to demonstrate the feasibility of multiparameter, almost-continuous monitoring of pavement subsurface courses enabled by embeddable BBRS; protocols that enable readout from thousands of densely dispersed embedded BBRS using mobile exciters and receivers; and physics-informed machine learning algorithms for evaluation of current condition and performance of monitored courses, and for predictive modeling of their deterioration over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
EAGER Project: "Collaborative Research: EAGER: Reliable Monitoring and Predictive Modeling for Safer Future Smart Transportation Structures"

Dates: 9/1/2023 - 8/31/2024 (1 year project)

The tests confirmed the feasibility of the proposed system and demonstrated excellent metrological performance of the embedded sensors in sand in laboratory conditions: for relative displacement in sand d1, sensitivity was 15.18°/cm with repeatability precision of 0.8 mm;  for strain change d2, sensitivity was 0.17°/με with repeatability precision of 900 με; for crack opening d3, sensitivity was 12.18°/cm with repeatability precision of 1.1 mm; finally, for change in relative sand humidity h,  sensitivity was 83.43°/% (where % denotes percentage of volumetric change in water content) with repeatability precision of ~0.01% volumetric change. While the sensitivity of the system to temperature was not tested due to lack of equipment and funds, the unintentional temperature changes that occurred during the tests confirmed sufficient sensitivity to detect changes of 1°C. Thus, the test results showed capability of the system in meeting the high metrological performance, which, based on literature review, enables  detection of distress in the subsurface layers of pavements.

In the area of machine learning methods for structural health monitoring, we have demonstrated that the proposed methodology, based on random Fourier feature Gaussian processes (GPs), performs well in the context of DGPs and accurately produces the desired posterior distributions. Furthermore, its extension to dynamic models also performs effectively.

In the area of MAC and routing protocols for the proposed system, we confirm the feasibility of for information dissemination in intermittent communication in the presence of limited information retention capability in communication environments with the practical set of parameters for the proposed system.

Through the objectives of this EAGER project, and the goals of this research, pavement containing embedded miniaturized RF sensors is transformed into a smart material with the potential to communicate its internal condition when inquired. Deployment of such material fundamentally transforms the physical composition of transportation infrastructure by moving from a passive, unknown, physical state to a material that can be interrogated. In addition, other sensing modalities (e.g., environmental monitoring, temperature, etc.), could be integrated in the future which will change the physical resources available at the infrastructure.

 


Last Modified: 10/13/2024
Modified by: Zygmunt J Haas

The tests confirmed the feasibility of the proposed system and demonstrated excellent metrological performance of the embedded sensors in sand in laboratory conditions: for relative displacement in sand d1, sensitivity was 15.18/cm with repeatability precision of 0.8 mm; for strain change d2, sensitivity was 0.17/ with repeatability precision of 900 ; for crack opening d3, sensitivity was 12.18/cm with repeatability precision of 1.1 mm; finally, for change in relative sand humidity h, sensitivity was 83.43/% (where % denotes percentage of volumetric change in water content) with repeatability precision of ~0.01% volumetric change. While the sensitivity of the system to temperature was not tested due to lack of equipment and funds, the unintentional temperature changes that occurred during the tests confirmed sufficient sensitivity to detect changes of 1C. In the area of machine learning methods for structural health monitoring, we have demonstrated that the proposed methodology, based on random Fourier feature Gaussian processes (GPs), performs well in the context of DGPs and accurately produces the desired posterior distributions.
